licence_note: Educational prototype dataset derived from general OTC knowledge, not real BNF content. Do not use for clinical care.

conditions.name: Headache (simple, non-migraine)
conditions.scope_note: For mild to moderate tension-type headaches in adults. Excludes migraine, cluster headache, head injury, or neurological symptoms.

red_flags.text: Sudden severe 'thunderclap' headache
Weakness, confusion, collapse, new slurred speech, vision loss, or seizure
red_flags.rationale: Possible stroke or acute neuro event.

red_flags.text: Headache following recent head injury
Fever with neck stiffness, photophobia, non‑blanching rash
Severe new headache in pregnancy or post‑partum
New headache age ≥ 50 years
Headache persists or worsens beyond 2 weeks
red_flags.rationale: Needs assessment to exclude secondary cause.

default_self_care: Rest, hydration, regular meals; avoid alcohol excess.
Consider sleep hygiene and stress reduction.
Limit screen time and take breaks.
Keep a simple headache diary if recurrent.

age_limits.note: For demo only; under‑16 dosing not included—refer to pharmacist.

pregnancy.note: Short‑term use acceptable at lowest effective dose.

options.dose_adult: 500 mg–1 g every 4–6 hours as needed; MAX 4 g in 24 hours (explanation only).
why: Gentle on stomach; generally safe in pregnancy if needed.
Avoid duplication with combination cold/flu products.
self_care: Avoid exceeding stated dose; check labels for paracetamol in other products.

breastfeeding.note: Small amounts in milk; generally compatible short‑term.

contraindications: active or history of peptic ulcer/bleed
options.dose_adult: 200–400 mg up to three times daily with food; short course (explanation only).
why: Anti‑inflammatory benefit if tension headache with muscular component.
self_care: Take with food; stop if indigestion, black stools, or wheeze.

conditions.name: Allergic rhinitis (hay fever)
conditions.scope_note: Seasonal or perennial symptoms: sneezing, itchy/runny nose, itchy eyes; exclude infection.

red_flags.text: Wheezing or shortness of breath
Frequent nosebleeds or unilateral blockage
Eye pain, photophobia, or visual loss

default_self_care: Allergen avoidance: close windows, shower after being outdoors, use wrap‑around sunglasses.
Regular saline nasal irrigation can help.
Check daily pollen forecast and pre‑dose before exposure.

age_limits.note: Under‑16 dosing not included in demo.

pregnancy.note: Loratadine or cetirizine often preferred if needed—seek pharmacist/GP advice.

breastfeeding.note: Small amounts in milk; monitor infant for drowsiness.

options.dose_adult: Once daily typical (explanation only).
why: Good symptom control with low sedation.
self_care: Avoid alcohol if drowsy; try at night first if unsure.

options.typical_use: Best for nasal congestion and overall control; start several days before peak exposure.

pregnancy.note: Use lowest effective dose; seek advice if needed.

options.dose_adult: 1–2 sprays per nostril once or twice daily (explanation only).
why: Reduce inflammation and congestion when used regularly.
self_care: Use daily; point nozzle away from septum; saline before steroid can improve effect.

conditions.name: Dyspepsia / Heartburn / Indigestion
conditions.scope_note: Burning behind breastbone or upper abdominal discomfort after meals; exclude alarm features.

red_flags.text: Difficulty swallowing or food getting stuck
Vomiting blood or black, tarry stools
Unintentional weight loss or persistent vomiting
New, persistent dyspepsia age ≥ 55
Chest pain on exertion, radiating to arm/jaw, or with breathlessness

default_self_care: Smaller meals; avoid late‑night eating; elevate head of bed for night symptoms.
Limit trigger foods/drinks: alcohol, spicy/fatty foods, caffeine, chocolate, mint.
Review NSAID use and smoking; weight management if needed.

interactions_flags: separate from other oral meds by 2–3 hours
options.dose_adult: After meals and at bedtime as required (explanation only).
why: Fast symptom relief; foam barrier for reflux.
self_care: Avoid lying flat after meals; watch trigger foods.

options.typical_use: Short course for frequent heartburn (≥ 2 days/week) when alginates insufficient.
options.dose_adult: 10 mg once daily for up to 14 days; see pack (explanation only).
why: Reduces gastric acid production for sustained control.
self_care: If symptoms persist >14 days or recur quickly, seek GP review.

conditions.name: Acute diarrhoea (adult)
conditions.scope_note: Loose or watery stools for < 72 hours without blood or high fever in otherwise healthy adult.

red_flags.text: Blood or mucus in stool, or black stools
High fever > 38.5°C or severe abdominal pain
Signs of dehydration (very drowsy, no urine in 8+ hours, dizziness/fainting)
Symptoms > 72 hours
Recent antibiotic use or hospital stay
Recent travel with fever
Pregnancy with significant symptoms

default_self_care: Prioritise oral rehydration; small, frequent sips. Eat light meals (BRAT not required).
Avoid alcohol; consider hand hygiene to reduce spread.
Stay off work/school for 48 hours after the last episode.

options.typical_use: First‑line for fluid and electrolyte replacement.

age_limits.note: Children require weight‑based dosing—outside demo scope.

options.dose_adult: Reconstitute per pack; sip frequently (explanation only).
why: Prevents dehydration; mainstay of treatment.
self_care: Use alongside light diet; continue usual meds unless advised otherwise.

options.typical_use: For short‑term control of diarrhoea when no blood/fever.
options.dose_adult: 2 mg initially, then 2 mg after each loose stool; MAX 16 mg/day (explanation only).
why: Reduces stool frequency and urgency.
self_care: Stop if constipation, abdominal swelling, or if no improvement after 48 hours.

conditions.name: Sore throat (acute)
conditions.scope_note: Painful throat for < 7 days without breathing difficulty; likely viral. Focus on analgesia and comfort.

red_flags.text: Difficulty breathing, drooling, or muffled voice
Severe one‑sided throat pain with trismus or swelling
Rash with high fever or very unwell
Symptoms > 7 days or recurrent episodes

default_self_care: Warm fluids or ice lollies; rest; avoid smoking.
Honey & lemon drinks can soothe (not for <1 year).
Gargling with warm salty water may help.

pregnancy.note: Paracetamol preferred if needed; avoid NSAIDs in pregnancy.

options.dose_adult: Use per pack for pain/fever (explanation only).
why: Mainstay of symptom relief.
self_care: Stay hydrated; consider alternating warm/cold drinks for comfort.

age_limits.note: Benzocaine not for children in this demo.

pregnancy.note: Seek pharmacist advice for local anaesthetics.

options.dose_adult: Per pack; maximum lozenges/day (explanation only).
why: Topical relief when swallowed is painful.
self_care: Do not exceed stated number; avoid prolonged use without review.

conditions.name: Common cold / nasal congestion
conditions.scope_note: Self‑limiting viral URTI with nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat; exclude influenza/COVID when relevant.

red_flags.text: Shortness of breath, chest pain, or severe systemic illness
red_flags.rationale: May indicate complications or alternative diagnosis.

red_flags.text: Symptoms persisting >10 days without improvement
Infant <2 with fever or poor feeding

default_self_care: Rest, fluids, and honey/lemon drinks (not for <1 year).
Saline nasal sprays/rinses can help.
Avoid smoking exposure; consider paracetamol/ibuprofen for aches if suitable.

options.dose_adult: 1 spray per nostril up to 2–3 times daily for max 7 days (explanation only).
why: Rapid decongestion; limit use to avoid rebound.
self_care: Limit to ≤7 days to prevent rebound congestion.

options.dose_adult: Use as needed (explanation only).
why: Safe option for most users.

options.dose_adult: Per pack; short courses only (explanation only).
why: Useful when topical not tolerated.
self_care: Avoid near bedtime due to stimulation.

conditions.name: Cough (dry or productive)
conditions.scope_note: Acute cough <3 weeks with cold; exclude red flags.

red_flags.text: Cough lasting ≥3 weeks
Coughing up blood, chest pain, breathlessness, high fever
Known asthma/COPD with worsening symptoms

default_self_care: Honey in warm drinks (not for <1 year).
Steam from a hot shower can soothe (avoid burns).
Stay hydrated; rest.

options.dose_adult: Per pack (explanation only).
why: Symptomatic relief; safe profile.

options.dose_adult: Per pack (explanation only).
why: May reduce cough frequency; avoid with MAOIs/SSRIs.

options.dose_adult: Per pack (explanation only).
why: May loosen mucus.

conditions.name: Constipation (uncomplicated)
conditions.scope_note: Infrequent or hard stools without concerning features.

red_flags.text: Unexplained rectal bleeding, weight loss, anaemia, or change in bowel habit >6 weeks (age ≥50)
Severe, persistent abdominal pain or vomiting
New constipation in age ≥55

default_self_care: Increase fluid and fibre intake; regular toilet routine after meals.
Activity/exercise as tolerated.
Review constipating meds (e.g., opioids, anticholinergics).

options.dose_adult: With plenty of water; effect in 24–72 h (explanation only).
why: Restores stool bulk/softness.

options.typical_use: Second‑line or if stool is hard
options.dose_adult: Per pack; effect in 24–48 h (lactulose slower) (explanation only).
why: Softens stool by drawing water into bowel.

options.dose_adult: At night for effect next morning (explanation only).
why: Increases bowel motility; short courses only.

conditions.name: Haemorrhoids (piles)
conditions.scope_note: Uncomplicated external haemorrhoids with itching/discomfort.

red_flags.text: Rectal bleeding with change in bowel habit, weight loss, anaemia
Severe pain/swelling (possible thrombosed pile)

default_self_care: Increase fibre, fluids; avoid straining and prolonged sitting.
Warm baths to soothe; gentle hygiene; avoid perfumed wipes.

options.dose_adult: Apply per pack; short courses (explanation only).
Max 7 days (explanation only).
why: Reduces inflammation; avoid long-term use.

conditions.name: Mouth ulcers (simple aphthous)
conditions.scope_note: Small recurrent aphthous ulcers (<1 cm), <3 weeks.

red_flags.text: Ulcer persisting >3 weeks, very large, or recurrent with systemic symptoms
Multiple widespread painful ulcers or suspected infection

default_self_care: Avoid spicy/acidic foods; use a soft toothbrush.
Consider vitamin/iron deficiency check if frequent.

options.typical_use: Reduce bacterial load; may aid healing
options.dose_adult: Rinse twice daily; avoid immediately before/after toothbrushing (explanation only).
Every 1.5–3 hours as needed (explanation only).

options.typical_use: For short‑term use in recurrent aphthous ulcers
options.dose_adult: Per pack; pharmacist advice required (explanation only).

conditions.name: Cold sores (herpes labialis)
conditions.scope_note: Tingling or blistering on lips; usually HSV‑1; treat early.

red_flags.text: Eye involvement or severe facial involvement
Very frequent or severe recurrences or immunocompromise

default_self_care: Avoid close contact when lesions active; keep hands clean.
Use separate towels; avoid picking.

options.dose_adult: Apply 5 times/day for ~5 days (explanation only).

conditions.name: Head lice (pediculosis capitis)
conditions.scope_note: Itchy scalp with visible lice or nits; treat all household contacts if needed.

red_flags.text: Eyelash involvement
Signs of secondary infection (weeping, crusting)

default_self_care: Wet‑combing with conditioner every 3–4 days for 2 weeks.
Check all close contacts; treat simultaneously.

options.dose_adult: Apply per pack; repeat after 7 days (explanation only).
Per pack (explanation only).

conditions.name: Threadworm (enterobiasis)
conditions.scope_note: Nocturnal perianal itch; visible small white worms.

red_flags.text: Weight loss, blood in stool, severe pain
Pregnancy with symptoms

default_self_care: Strict hand hygiene; short nails; morning shower to remove eggs; daily towel/bed linen changes for 2 weeks.
Treat household contacts simultaneously.

options.typical_use: Single dose repeat in 2 weeks; pharmacist‑supplied
options.dose_adult: Single 100 mg dose; repeat in 2 weeks (explanation only).

conditions.name: Superficial fungal infections (athlete’s foot, ringworm, jock itch)
conditions.scope_note: Localised tinea corporis/cruris/pedis without nail/scalp involvement.

red_flags.text: Nail or scalp involvement
Widespread rash or failure of OTC after 2–4 weeks

default_self_care: Keep area clean/dry; change socks/underwear daily; avoid sharing towels.
Continue treatment for 1–2 weeks after rash clears.

options.dose_adult: Apply 2–3 times daily (explanation only).
Once/twice daily for 1–2 weeks (explanation only).

conditions.name: Dry skin / eczema / contact dermatitis (mild)
conditions.scope_note: Mild dry, itchy, inflamed skin without infection.

red_flags.text: Weeping, yellow crusts, or rapidly worsening redness/pain
Widespread severe eczema or failure of emollients/steroid after 7 days

default_self_care: Use generous, frequent emollients; soap substitutes; avoid known irritants.
Apply topical steroids thinly once daily for flares, short course only on appropriate sites.

options.dose_adult: Apply liberally and often (explanation only).

options.typical_use: Short course mild steroid for body (not face/genitals/broken skin)
options.dose_adult: Once daily up to 7 days (explanation only).

conditions.name: Dry eye disease
conditions.scope_note: Grittiness, burning, fluctuating vision; worse with screens, wind, air‑con.

red_flags.text: Acute painful red eye, photophobia, or reduced vision
Persistent unilateral symptoms or discharge

default_self_care: Follow 20‑20‑20 rule for screens; blink consciously.
Use preservative‑free lubricants if frequent dosing.

options.dose_adult: As needed; separate from other eye meds (explanation only).
Per pack (explanation only).

conditions.name: Earwax (cerumen impaction)
conditions.scope_note: Fullness, reduced hearing without pain/discharge.

red_flags.text: Ear pain, discharge, fever, or suspected perforation/grommets

default_self_care: Use softeners for several days before any irrigation by a professional.
Do not insert cotton buds.

options.dose_adult: 2–3 drops 2–3 times daily for several days (explanation only).
Per pack (explanation only).

conditions.name: Insect bites & stings (uncomplicated)
conditions.scope_note: Localised itch/swelling without systemic symptoms.

red_flags.text: Breathing difficulty, lip/tongue swelling, dizziness
Increasing redness, warmth, pain, pus or fever

default_self_care: Wash with soap/water; apply cold pack; avoid scratching.
Consider antihistamine for itch; hydrocortisone 1% short course for inflammation (age limits apply).

options.dose_adult: Once daily typical (explanation only).

options.typical_use: Short course for inflammation (not on broken skin/face)
options.dose_adult: Max 7 days (explanation only).

conditions.name: Muscular aches, sprains & strains (incl. acute lower back pain without radiculopathy)
conditions.scope_note: Minor soft‑tissue injuries without red flags; early gentle movement preferred.

red_flags.text: Back pain with leg weakness/numbness, bowel/bladder issues, or saddle anaesthesia
Severe trauma or suspected fracture

default_self_care: Relative rest 24–48 h, then gradual mobilisation; heat for stiffness, ice for swelling.
Consider physio advice and posture/ergonomics.

options.dose_adult: 500 mg–1 g every 4–6 h, max 4 g/day (explanation only).
200–400 mg up to TID with food (explanation only).

options.typical_use: Local pain relief with lower systemic exposure
options.dose_adult: Apply 3–4 times daily (explanation only).

conditions.name: Vaginal thrush (vulvovaginal candidiasis) — pharmacist referral
conditions.scope_note: Itching, soreness, thick white discharge; treat via pharmacist‑supplied options when appropriate.

red_flags.text: First episode or uncertain diagnosis
Pregnancy
≥4 episodes/year or symptoms after OTC treatment

default_self_care: Avoid perfumed soaps; wear breathable cotton underwear.
Complete full course if treated; avoid sexual activity if very sore.

conditions.name: Uncomplicated UTI (women 16–64) — triage only
conditions.scope_note: Dysuria, frequency, urgency without vaginal symptoms; pharmacist assessment recommended.

red_flags.text: Fever, flank pain, nausea/vomiting
Pregnancy, male, children, or recurrent UTIs
Vaginal discharge or irritation

default_self_care: Increase fluids; consider urinary alkalinising sachets for comfort (limited evidence).
Seek pharmacist assessment for potential Pharmacy First pathway.

global_rules.reason: Aspirin is contraindicated in under‑16s due to risk of Reye’s syndrome (except on medical advice).
Avoid NSAIDs during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester.
NSAIDs increase risk of GI bleeding and renal adverse effects.
Avoid sympathomimetic decongestants with monoamine oxidase inhibitors.
Rebound congestion risk with prolonged use; limit to ≤7 days.
Risk of serotonin syndrome with MAOIs/SSRIs.
Do not use mild topical steroids on face/genitals or broken skin without medical advice.

copy.disclaimer: Educational demo only — not medical advice. Always follow pack instructions and seek care if unsure. In emergencies call 999.
copy.emergency_text: Call 999 for severe chest pain, difficulty breathing, severe bleeding, or if someone is very unwell or hard to wake.
